abstract_sentences.1: We introduce a Multi-modal Neural Machine Translation model in which a doubly-attentive decoder naturally incorporates spatial visual features obtained using pre-trained convolutional neural networks, bridging the gap between image description and translation.
abstract_sentences.2: Our decoder learns to attend to source-language words and parts of an image independently by means of two separate attention mechanisms as it generates words in the target language.
abstract_sentences.3: We find that our model can efficiently exploit not just back-translated in-domain multi-modal data but also large general-domain text-only MT corpora.
abstract_sentences.4: We also report state-of-the-art results on the Multi30k data set.

https://doi.org/10.18653/v1/P17-1175  1 Introduction  Neural Machine Translation (NMT) has been successfully tackled as a sequence to sequence learning problem (Kalchbrenner and Blunsom, 2013; Cho et al., 2014b; Sutskever et al., 2014) where each training example consists of one source and one target variable-length sequences, with no prior information on the alignment between the two.
body_sentences.2: In the context of NMT, Bahdanau et al.
body_sentences.3: (2015) first proposed to use an attention mechanism in the decoder, which is trained to attend to the relevant source-language words as it generates each word of the target sentence.
body_sentences.5: (2015) proposed an attention-based model for the task of image description generation (IDG) where a model learns to attend to specific parts of an image representation (the source) as it generates its description (the target) in natural language.
body_sentences.6: We are inspired by recent successes in applying attention-based models to NMT and IDG.

body_sentences.10: To the best of our knowledge, previous MNMT models in the literature that utilised spatial visual features did not significantly improve over a comparable model that used global visual features or even only textual features (Caglayan et al., 2016a; Calixto et al., 2016; Huang et al., 2016; Libovický et al., 2016; Specia et al., 2016).
body_sentences.11: In this work, we wish to address this issue and propose an MNMT model that uses, in addition to an attention mechanism over the source-language words, an additional visual attention mechanism to incorporate spatial visual features, and still improves on simpler text-only and multi-modal attention-based NMT models.

body_sentences.64: 4 Data  The Flickr30k data set contains 30k images and 5 descriptions in English for each image (Young et al., 2014).
body_sentences.65: In this work, we use the Multi30k dataset (Elliott et al., 2016), which consists of two multilingual expansions of the original Flickr30k: one with translated data and another one with comparable data, henceforth referred to as M30kT and M30kC, respectively.
body_sentences.66: For each of the 30k images in the Flickr30k, the M30kT has one of the English descriptions manually translated into German by a professional translator.
body_sentences.67: Training, validation and test sets contain 29k, 1,014 and 1k images respectively, each accompanied by a sentence pair (the original English sentence and its translation into German).
body_sentences.68: For each of the 30k images in the Flickr30k, the M30kC has five descriptions in German collected independently from the English descriptions.
body_sentences.69: Training, validation and test sets contain 29k, 1,014 and 1k images respectively, each accompanied by five sentences in English and five sentences in German.
body_sentences.70: We use the entire M30kT training set for training our MNMT models, its validation set for model selection with BLEU (Papineni et al., 2002), and its test set for evaluation.
body_sentences.71: In addition, since the amount of training data available is small, we build a back-translation model using the text-only NMT model described in §2.1 trained on the Multi30kT data set (German→English and English→German), without images.
body_sentences.72: We use this model to back-translate the 145k German (English) descriptions in the Multi30kC into English (German) and include the triples (synthetic English description, German description, image) when translating into German, and the triples (synthetic German description, English description, image) when translating into English, as additional training data (Sennrich et al., 2016a).
body_sentences.73: We also use the WMT 2015 text-only parallel corpora available for the English–German language pair, consisting of about 4.3M sentence pairs (Bojar et al., 2015).

body_sentences.76: We use the scripts in the Moses SMT Toolkit (Koehn et al., 2007) to normalise and tokenize English and German descriptions, and we also convert space-separated tokens into subwords (Sennrich et al., 2016b).

body_sentences.79: We train models to translate from English into German, as well as for German into English, and report evaluation of cased, tokenized sentences with punctuation.
body_sentences.80: 5 Experimental setup  Our encoder is a bidirectional RNN with GRU, one 1024D single-layer forward and one 1024D single-layer backward RNN.
body_sentences.81: Source and target word embeddings are 620D each and trained jointly with the model.
body_sentences.82: Word embeddings and other non-recurrent matrices are initialised by sampling from a Gaussian N (0, 0.012), recurrent matrices are random orthogonal and bias vectors are all initialised to zero.
body_sentences.83: Visual features are obtained by feeding images to the pre-trained ResNet-50 and using the activations of the res4f layer (He et al., 2015).
body_sentences.84: We apply dropout with a probability of 0.5 in the encoder bidirectional RNN, the image features, the decoder RNN and before emitting a target word.
body_sentences.85: We follow Gal and Ghahramani (2016) and apply dropout to the encoder bidirectional and the decoder RNN using one same mask in all time steps.
body_sentences.86: All models are trained using stochastic gradient descent with ADADELTA (Zeiler, 2012) with minibatches of size 80 (text-only NMT) or 40 (MNMT), where each training instance consists of one English sentence, one German sentence and one image (MNMT).
body_sentences.87: We apply early stopping for model selection based on BLEU4, so that if a model does not improve on BLEU4 in the validation set for more than 20 epochs, training is halted.
body_sentences.88:
The translation quality of our models is evaluated quantitatively in terms of BLEU4 (Papineni et al., 2002), METEOR (Denkowski and Lavie, 2014), TER (Snover et al., 2006), and
chrF3 (Popović, 2015).3 We report statistical significance with approximate randomisation for the first three metrics with MultEval (Clark et al., 2011).
body_sentences.89: 5.1 Baselines  We train a text-only phrase-based SMT (PBSMT) system and a text-only NMT model for comparison (English→German and German→English).
body_sentences.90: Our PBSMT baseline is built with Moses and uses a 5–gram LM with modified Kneser-Ney smoothing (Kneser and Ney, 1995).
body_sentences.91: It is trained on the English→German (German→English) descriptions of the M30kT, whereas its LM is trained on the German (English) descriptions only.
body_sentences.92: We use minimum error rate training to tune the model with BLEU (Och, 2003).
body_sentences.93: The text-only NMT baseline is the one described in §2.1 and is trained on the M30kT’s English–German descriptions, again in both language directions.
body_sentences.94: When translating into German, we also compare our model against two publicly available results obtained with multi-modal attention-based NMT models.
body_sentences.95: The first model is Huang et al.
body_sentences.96: (2016)’s best model trained on the same data, and the second is their best model using additional object detections, respectively models m1 (image at head) and m3 in the authors’ paper.

body_sentences.119: Pre-training We now discuss results for models pre-trained using different data sets.
body_sentences.120: We first pre-trained the two text-only baselines PBSMT and NMT, and our MNMT model on the backtranslated M30kC, a medium-sized in-domain image description data set (145k training instances), in both directions.
body_sentences.121: We also pre-trained the same models on the English–German parallel sentences of much larger MT data sets, i.e.
body_sentences.122: the concatenation of the Europarl (Koehn, 2005), Common Crawl and News Commentary corpora, used in WMT 2015 (∼4.3M parallel sentences).
body_sentences.124: used the concatenation of the pretraining and training data for training, and model PBSMT (LM) used the general-domain German sentences as additional data to train the LM.
body_sentences.125: From Tables 1 and 2, it is clear that model NMTSRC+IMG can learn from both in-domain, multi-modal pretraining data sets as well as text-only, general domain ones.
body_sentences.126: Pre-training on M30kC When pre-training on the back-translated M30kC and translating into German, the recall-oriented chrF3 shows a difference of 1.4 points between PBSMT and our model, mostly due to character recall; nonetheless, our model still improved by the same margin on the text-only NMT baseline.
body_sentences.127: Our model still outperforms the PBSMT baseline according to BLEU4 and TER, and the text-only NMT baseline according to all metrics (p < .05).
body_sentences.128: When translating into English, model NMTSRC+IMG still consistently scores higher according to all metrics evaluated, although the differences between its translations and those obtained with the NMT baseline are no longer statistically significant (p < 0.01).

body_sentences.144: 6 Related work  Multi-modal MT was just recently addressed by the MT community by means of a shared task (Specia et al., 2016).
body_sentences.145: However, there has been a considerable amount of work on natural language generation from non-textual inputs.

body_sentences.148: In their work, the authors incorporate global image features in a separate multi-modal layer that merges the RNN textual representations and the global image features.

dependent, non-attentive neural image description models.5 Venugopalan et al.

body_sentences.155: (2015) introduced the first attention-based IDG model where an attentive decoder learns to attend to different parts of an image as it generates its description in natural language.
body_sentences.156: In the context of NMT, Zoph and Knight (2016) introduced a multi-source attention-based NMT model trained to translate a pair of sentences in two different source languages into a target language, and reported considerable improvements over a single-source baseline.
body_sentences.158: (2015) proposed a multi-task learning approach where a model is trained to translate from one source language into multiple target languages.
body_sentences.160: (2016) put forward a multi-way model trained to translate between many different source and target languages.

body_sentences.169: Although no purely neural multi-modal model to date significantly improves on both text-only NMT and SMT models (Specia et al., 2016), different research groups have proposed to include global and spatial visual features in re-ranking n-best lists generated by an SMT system or directly in an NMT framework with some success (Caglayan et al., 2016a; Calixto et al., 2016; Huang et al., 2016; Libovický et al., 2016; Shah et al., 2016).
body_sentences.170: To the best of our knowledge, the best published results of a purely MNMT model are those of Huang et al.
body_sentences.171: (2016), who proposed to use global visual features extracted with the VGG19 network (Simonyan and Zisserman, 2015) for an entire image, and also for regions of the image obtained using the RCNN of Girshick et al.
body_sentences.173: Their best model improves over a strong text-only NMT baseline and is comparable to results obtained with an SMT model trained on the same data.
body_sentences.174: For that reason, their models are used as baselines in our experiments whenever possible.
body_sentences.175: Our work differs from previous work in that, first, we propose attention-based MNMT models.
body_sentences.176: This is an important difference since the use of attention in NMT has become standard and is the current state-of-the-art (Jean et al., 2015; Luong et al., 2015; Firat et al., 2016; Sennrich et al., 2016b).
body_sentences.177: Second, we propose a doublyattentive model where we effectively fuse two mono-modal attention mechanisms into one multimodal decoder, training the entire model jointly and end-to-end.
body_sentences.178: Additionally, we are interested in how to merge textual and visual representations into multi-modal representations when generating words in the target language, which differs substantially from text-only translation tasks even when these translate from many source languages and/or into many target languages (Dong et al., 2015; Firat et al., 2016; Zoph and Knight, 2016).

body_sentences.183: Additionally, NMTSRC+IMG has been applied to the machine translation of user-generated product listings from an e-commerce website, while also making use of the product images to improve translations (Calixto et al., 2017b,a).
body_sentences.184: 7 Conclusions and Future Work  We have introduced a novel attention-based, multi-modal NMT model to incorporate spatial visual information into NMT.
body_sentences.185: We have reported state-of-the-art results on the M30kT test set, improving on previous multi-modal attention-based models.
body_sentences.186: We have also showed that our model can be efficiently pre-trained on both mediumsized back-translated in-domain multi-modal data as well as also large general-domain text-only MT corpora, finding that it is able to exploit the additional data regardless of the domain.
body_sentences.187: Our model also compares favourably to both NMT and PBSMT baselines evaluated on the same training data.
body_sentences.188: In the future, we will incorporate coverage into our model and study how to apply it to other Natural Language Processing tasks.
